It's called dgVoodoo and is referred to in this Steam discussion thread: http://steamcommunity.com/app/32380/discussions/0/535152511375864645/. You can also download it from the developer's website: http://dege.freeweb.hu/. It's not perfect, but if it works for you, it will make the game much less frustrating to load and play.Some other fixes which folks have reported success with, but which did not work for me:* You can try using Compatibility Modes in Windows, and nVidia users may be able to make use of a legacy driver. Check out this guide for more information: 


How to get this game to work on windows 10 without installing any mods 
A Guide for STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II
By: TheBombasticWafflez

			This guide tells you how I got the game to work on Windows 10 without the use of any mods.

 DISCLAIMER: THIS GAME TAKES A BIT OF WORK TO RUN PROPERLY AND THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS  Brief overview:  Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is the first game in the Jedi Knight series. Taking place several years after the events of Dark Forces I. Albeit being non canon as of now, Dark Forces II chronologically take place one year after the Battle of Endor. I remember having fond memories if this game when I was younger, about five or six years old when I played this game for the first time. The game itself is very enjoyable, but a common complaint is that the level design can be confusing at times, it is easy to pick up the trail again though, usually by taking a second look at certain things in the level. But that's definitely not anything to take away from the overall experience.  Summary of the first few minutes  You play as Kyle Katarn, an Imperial Officer turned Rebel mercenary, strung up in a bar at a city of Nar Shadda, viewing a recording of his father, remarking how proud he was of Kyle after graduating from the Imperial Academy. It ends when to be held up by a droid named 8t88 and some thugs he hired, Kyle asks 88 for information, as he desired to know who murdered his father. The droid tells Kyle that it was the Dark Jedi known as Jerec, mentions how he has great plans for the rebirth of the Galactic Empire, before 88 tells his goons to waste Kyle, he soons shows Kyle a mysterious disk, asking what he knows about it, so his men won't "indulge their darker side". Kyle, having no knowledge about it remarks he's been to the Dark side. 88 soon walks away, concluding his business. You'll just have to play the game to find out what happens next. The weapons  Aww yeah, the good stuff. There's a pretty nice variety of them, ranging from blasters, to rail detonators, to concussion rifles, to lightsabers. Bryar Pistol  Kyle's personal blaster pistol, not particually powerful. But it is more accurate for long range shooting. Uses Energy Cells. BlasTech E-11 Carbine/"Stormtrooper Rifle"  One of the more common weapon found, especially early in the game, commonly used by Gran thugs and later, normal Stormtroopers and ones with orange shoulder pauldrons. It appears to be somewhat more powerful than the Bryar, but it fires much faster, but at the cost of being much less accurate at long ranges. Also uses Energy Cells. Wookiee Bowcaster  Ah yes, Chewbacca's personal weapon of choice. More accurate and much more poweful than the Bryar and E-11, it is used by some Tusken thugs. It can be charged up to fire multiple bolts at once, similar to that of a shotgun. Uses Power Cells. Thermal Detonators  The equivalent to hand grenades, can be very helpful in certain situations. Useful for taking out grouped up enemies. Imperial Repeater Rifle  More or less a direct upgrade to the E-11, fires much faster, a bit weaker in terms of firepower, but it's makes up for it in accuracy, as its bolts fire in a straight line. It has an alt fire where it fires three bolts at once in a triangle formation. It's always used by Stormtroopers with red shoulder pauldrons. Also uses Power Cells. Rail Detonator  This one is fun to use, the game's equivalent of a rocket launcher. Primary fires launches a projectile that explodes on contact, alt fire makes the projectile stick to something, or someone and detonates over time. It's always used by Stormtroopers with yellow shoulder pauldrons. Uses Rail Charges. Concussion Rifle  This one is also another fun weapon to use, more or less a rail gun that packs a mighty punch and kicks really hard, to the point where it knocks Kyle back a bit. Much different compared to it's previous incarnation seen in Dark Forces I. It fires a solid bolt, with a large blast radius causing heavy damage to anyone unfortunate enough to get caught in it. Alt fire is a non-explosive shot that acts like a traditional rail gun. Again, also uses Power Cells. Sequencer Charges  Basic explosive charge, handy for choke points. I didn't use it as much though.  Lightsaber  The weapon of the Jedi and Sith alike. A very powerful weapon, capable of deflecting blaster bolts and can kill most enemies in just a single strike.  The Enemies to Shoot At  Gran thug  Common enemies, usually equipped with an E-11, their fists, or thermal detonators. Easy to dispatch. Rodian thug  Oh hey, it's Greedo. Oh wait. These guys are somewhat more uncommon, only armed with a blaster pistol and deal minimal damage, they're just as easy to dispatch. Tusken mercenary  These guys eventually replace the Gran thugs somewhat early in game. They're commonly armed with E-11s or Wookie Bowcasters. They can be dangerous in groups. Stormtroopers  The most common enemy you'll face through out the rest of the game, standard Stormtroopers and ones with orange shoulder pauldrons are armed with E-11 blasters. The difference between the two is the amount of health. There are two other variants.  "Repeater Trooper"  A variant of the Stormtrooper, signified with their red shoulder pauldron, and armed with the Repeater Rifle. "Rail Trooper"  Another variant, signified with their yellow shoulder pauldron, as well as being armed with the Rail Detonator. They're the more dangerous type of trooper, if Kyle gets close to one, they'll actually whack him on the head with their weapon, dealing moderate damage. Trandoshan mercs  The guys that look like Bossk, they're the most dangerous enemy to face. As they're armed with Concussion Rifles, and have a good amount of health to boot as well. Getting close to one will also result them whacking Kyle on the head with their weapon as well.  Imperial Officers  Similar to the Rodian thug, armed with a blaster pistol and very easy to dispatch. Imperial Commandos  Better than Stormtroopers, usually armed with Repeater Rifles. They have more health, due to the fact they can survive one strike from a lightsaber. Some other cool enemies too  Play the game to find out. Conclusion  Should you play it? Well, if you're a die-hard Star Wars fan, then yes. You should, but the experience may not be pleasant for some, as the Steam version is difficult to get working properly. And those who are from the "modern" gaming era, you're probably not gonna enjoy the game as much as I did. As its lengthy level design and complex level design will probably confuse those and give up. But that's their fault for giving up, right?

Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II			* 7/10Kyle Katarn is back again, and the moment he grabs a lightsaber he will magically become a powerful jedi without even training!Yeah, as a huge Star Wars fan, that was the only thing I kind of "disrespect" from this chapter, but considering the epic proportion of the story and the consequent legacy I kind of let it go.In this chapter Kyle Katarn is after his father's murderer and this quest will take him to a journey full of discovery and surprises as He is destined to find a lightsaber and become a Jedi in order to confront himself with his father's murderer: Jerec, a Sith Lord followed by his six disciples.So according to the story the biggest news in this game lies in the gameplay. Kyle will start as in Dark Forces with his blaster, making his way with laser shots, but the moment he finds the lightsaber the game will suggest you a third person view (you can use a first person camera if you prefer, but I never did). This will be useful to better control Kyle during lightsaber fights, use of force powers and jumps... Long and very high jumps. This game was a great innovation for its time as it's the first successful attempt to give the player the control of a jedi knight in action (and no, fight tournaments doesn't count at all...), with force powers and all. Of course, it's very crude and unripe, animations are really simple (not to mention the coarse secondary lightsaber attack), force powers are a little cluncky to control at first, but everything comes more handy with time. Another very important part of this game is the double ending. Kyle can end being a Jedi (Canonic ending) or fall to the dark side, and everything according to your behaviour ingame, for example with civilians, or when you choose which force power to improve (you can choose between, neutral, light and dark powers).Of Course it can't be a Star Wars game without the original amazing soundtrack from John Williams. Unfortunately they're no longer dynamic tracks as in Dark Forces and the music doesn't loop immediately so there wil be moments of silence which kind of ruin the atmosphere.Levels are pretty big, and with some little puzzles involving switches and timings, but the most particular side inherited by Dark Forces is the maze-like structure sided with hidden passages. To go ahead you have to find THAT hidden passage and this leads to the next place, and this can be sometimes very frustrating, especially in the falling ship level, for example. But that's an example of a good thing as well, as there are levels and situations designed with creativity, with the falling ship being the best example of this.Unfortunately the game shows its age really bad. Very low polys for models and levels, low resolution textures, the lightsaber looks made of plastic not to mention the very LOW compatibility on modern systems. I had to apply patches and look for more alternatives to get past glitches and very bad issues, but at last I've successfully made it playable. There are also patches that improve a little some textures and the lightsaber effect. At least it compensate with something quite rare: cutscenes with real actors! I wouldn't give any of the actors, nor the FX crew an oscar but I just love them and they did a good job especially if you consider when this was done.+++PROs+++ STORY. Definitely a very good story with everything, Kyle, Jan Ors, the Foe Jerec, his disciples, all with different motivations and nature, great situations and surprises. Everything told ingame or with Live-Action cutscenes! JEDI! For the first time we get to move and control a Jedi, with a lightsaber and force powers. ...OR SITH? It's not supposed to be a canon part of the story but your behaviour is monitored and your choices and actions will tip the balance towards the light or dark side giving different endings. SOUNDTRACK. Of course there's always the amazing music from the Original Star Wars soundtrack.---CONs--- SOUNDTRACK. ...But unlike its predecessor and successor it isn't a dynamic soundtrack that alternates calm tracks in exploring situations and more active music during fights. Besides the music won't loop immediately leaving moments of silence. STORY. "Grab a lightsaber -> become a Jedi" is a very wrong axiom, but I'm too kind and I forgive them for this simplification. LOW-COMPATIBILITY ISSUES. This game is very old and of course issues and glitch were expected. My first attempt resulted in a black screen ingame with all sounds and events running, or completely inverted/pixel-blasted textures. Luckily, after GTA IV I've gained enough patience to read deeply the Steam Community to find different solutions and patches, and I've made it work eventually... Too bad that seems like the GOG release is already patched and fully working... -.- LEVELS STRUCTURE. Especially in the last sections they're really tough, with some particular puzzles or a mandatory too well hidden passage for the next place. It requires very good observation and attention to details.

Dark Forces II was, arguably, one of the best shooters of its day. Provided that you don't mind a bit of effort to get the game up and running properly, the follow-up to the original DOS classic is well worth a look, providing an excellent example of how great a licensed title can be and the capability of its now defunct developer LucasArts.Jedi Knight places you once more in the role of Kyle Katarn, a battle-hardened, side-switching mercenary of the expanded universe. Taking place a short time after the events of Episode VI, a small corrupted faction of the Empire's remnants known as the Dark Jedi are in pursuit of the legendary Valley of the Jedi and the unstoppable power that it supposedly grants. With an obvious interest in tracking them down, the inevitable confrontation allows you a chance to avenge the death of his family.A huge step-up in terms of narrative alone, JK is also a significant depature from its predecessor in most respects. Levels are now bigger and more sprawling than ever but not baffling to explore, and there are plenty of hidden surprises across the various locations of the campaign. Sound is no longer technically limited by the MIDI format of the early '90s and John Williams' score plays on top of all the classic sound effects taken straight from the films. Combat is more refined and easy to get into and enjoy, with an impressive range of weapons on offer rather than an over-reliance on the Stormtrooper's blaster rifle or thermal detonators. The introduction of lightsaber combat is also worthy of note, though is admittedly prone to clunky, hack-and-slash gameplay. Unlike the atrocious in-engine rendering of Mysteries of the Sith, JK uses the classic (almost nostalgic) combination of live-action and early CGI to establish the fairly well written narrative during the frequent (and occasionally lengthy) cutscenes. Most of the cast seemed to have thoroughly enjoyed acting in them and in-game dialogue uses the same high quality voices, which is a nice touch. As one who has never been that invested or interested in Star Wars, (I've only seen the six episodes once and have little interest in the reboots), I was pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable this turned out to be. Having picked up the entire Jedi Knight collection and Battlefront II during the recent sale, it's encouraging to see licensed titles that are actually decent and, more to the point, satisfying to play. The game certainly does have compatibility issues, (considering it's age), and requires a decent amount of time to tweak, fix and optimise for modern PCs. Yet it is a relatively straight-forward process and there a plenty of excellent guides and tutorials available in the community hub here to help you get it going. As a result, I really can recommend Jedi Knight - Dark Forces II; a shooter that caters to pretty much everyone. It is a vastly superior experience compared to the first yet still retains the depth and style of it's now non-canon lore. Star Wars fans will have an absolute blast playing through this, undoubtedly coming back for more playthroughs, and for those such as myself, it provides an excellent example of the '90s shooter and a worthy alternative to Doom or Quake. Thumbs up.

Kyle Katarn is trying to track down his fathers murderer, and along the way discovers he has force powers, and must fight the Dark Jedi Jerec by finding someplace called "The Valley of the Jedi".OS and Purchasing alternatives to consider: So just to clear up a few things people might want to know going into the gameplay section. I played this game on windows 10 and it's definitely not optimized very well for the system, but at least I was able to play it.Also some people have had mechanical problems with the game and recomend using GoG, I don't have it on GoG so I can't testify to it's superiority, but I can at least pass along the information that it's worth consideration.Gameplay: Dark Forces II starts out as a straight up FPS, but after the first three levels it shifts into a hybrid Star Wars Jedi FPS... if that makes any sense? You're now equipped with a lightsaber and a few force powers (As you progress through the game you get new force powers and can chose between the light or dark side, and your choice will impact the end game cinematic!), however you can still run through the game gunning like you would for Dark Forces 1! The only parts of the game where you don't have much choice is the few selective duels you engage the Dark Jedi in.It might be worth noting that you cannot defect attacks or blaster bolts if you're attacking, so timing with the lightsaber is key....Also it's worth noting that the default control scheme is really really weird, right click to jump, and space bar to interact.  ...Why would they do that? Because your E key is used to toggle through force powers.The good news is you can rebind your keys, so I'd recommend you do that. (and turn off the Y-Axis invert)Conclusion: Taken as a whole, this game isn't that bad! I always wanted to play it as a kid, and I'm glad I finally got around to playing it now. However, many people are correct in criticizing it's performance, and Kudos to anyone who goes through the hoops to improve the game.I'm stubborn and willing to work with lower and weirdly stretched graphics, and I still thoroughly enjoyed my play through.

												After several years of this game being completely broken on Steam, Disney Interactive has stepped up and released a patch.Despite the fact that it predates their acquisition, despite the fact that it probably isn't a huge money maker, they did this. For that, they've earned my respect.Before the patch, the game didn't work in fullscreen properly, the music was entirely missing, and was highly prone to crashing. The update has fixed all of these issues. There are still issues with 3D Acceleration mode, limiting you on the color depth, but I'm hoping those will be fixed as well.Beyond the technical aspects, my review of the game follows:This is an old game. It is not a pretty game, and it is not a polished game. It is a very good game for the time, and if you either grew up with it, or can go back and appreciate classic titles, it is well worth full asking price, let alone sale price. I grew up with the Jedi Knight series, so I'm applying a heavy helping of rose-tint nostalgia paste to my goggles. That said, it is still a fun, though at times puzzling and confusing game. It's from that era of shooters where we were just starting to experiment with platforming elements and puzzles, and as a result, it can get very frustrating on both.Quicksave is your friend, you will need it. The Medium and Hard difficulties are brutal, par for the course at the time. Those of you who grew up with 90s-early 2000s PC shooters know what to expect, and the game is a blast if you enjoy that kind of run-and-gun gameplay.The story is fairly cheesy, read the accompanying novels, if you can find and stomach them, as they shed light on a lot of details the game glosses over.Overall, before the update, I probably would only recommend this to hardcore fans of the series, but now that it works out of the box, I think I can recommend it for anyone who's interested in the history of the series or PC gaming in general.

												What is it with Nar Shadda? The place has featured at least three times over the course of the Dark Forces Saga and once in KOTOR II, and it was the weakest part of the game every time. There's just something about the Smuggler's Moon that lends itself to rubbish level design.Anyway, after checking a few guides on getting the damn thing to run, I finally got Dark Forces II to play. The game starts out a bit rocky, as most of your ammunition is scavanaged off of your fallen enemies, an ineffective strategy when about half of your enemies come at you with good old fisticuffs. This led to a few occasions when I had to take out a dozen enemies with six blaster shots and my own punches, and sadly it seems Kyle hasn't been working out quite like he used to as the fists that could once drop a Kell Dragon are barely enough to put down passing thugs.Fortunately once you get off Nar Shadda, enemies are universally packing heat, and the game starts to come to life. Ugly, early full-3D life, but life nonetheless. The level design is somewhere between the original Dark Force's nonlinear approach and Jedi Outcast's straight shot from start to finish, and manages to have the strengths and weaknesses of both. The levels are truly impressive in size, and lead to some memorable setpieces (most dramatic, if relatively brief, of which is a scene when you're left trying to sprint for the hangar bay of a ship in freefall), but they also follow a highly specific thread of advancement that, while not so bad as Dark Force's tendancy to block off progression to people who can't use sideways moon logic, still can leave you poking around a level for half an hour looking for the solitary path forward. Perhaps they felt the necessity due to the actual presence of maps in the game, but the locations beat out Jedi Outcasts in that their layout actually seems to have something to do with the location you're alledgedly visiting (for example, a starship whose rooms are actually laid out in the shape of a starship).However, despite the strengths I mention, I ultimately can't recommend the game because its sprawling design isn't quite as good as Dark Forces, and its storyline isn't as good as Jedi Outcast's, lacking relatable characters and quite often much of a plot at all. For example, once you aquire a lightsaber from your father's droid, you start using Force powers without training, or indeed any exposition that you had any Force potential at all (the lightsaber isn't even your father's, so a hereditary connection isn't implied either). Just "here's a lightsaber, start using superpowers." Not to mention the lightsaber is basically useless in this game. Sure it can deflect blaster shots if you're facing in the right direction, but I ultimatley wound up using my normal weapons for 99% of the game, only pulling out my lightsaber to cut open grates and fight the bosses.Speaking of which, apart from the game's tendancy to dump you somewhere with not much more than a cursory mention of why you were there (such as letting me run around in a fuel depot for an hour before I actually realize that I'm trying to use it to sneak onto a ship through the fuel lines), the bosses are also generally pretty weak. Unlike the first enemy you make in the game, the sleazy protocol droid 8t88, who obviously can't put up anything resembling a fight, all of the bosses are the main villain Jerec's Dark Jedi cronies, who mostly just stand around in the background of expository cutscenes until they randomly turn up at the end of certain levels for a boss fight apiece. Who are they? Dunno. A smug twit, a domanatrix, a big-guy-little-guy alien duo, and a giggling Twi'lek who I'm reasonably certain was brain damaged. That's about the extent of characterization you get. As for the fight themselves, they weren't as luck-based as Jedi Outcast and Academy's Dark Jedi fights, but they gave very little indication of how well you were doing so I usually just jumped around clicking my very slow attack button until the bad guy fell down.Ultimately, between the compatibility issues with modern machines, the weak plot, and the occasionally frustrating gameplay (looking at you, rocket Stormtroopers), I can't really recommend bothering with this entry just to enjoy its middling-quality level design.-----I recently went back to play this one, and at first I thought it might be a similar case to Jedi Outcast, where a second playthrough was giving me a better outlook on the game. This, however, turned out not to be the case. Nar Shadda was a pain as before, for the same reason of simply not having enough gun-toting enemies to supply your ammunition needs. However, things picked up again afterwards, roughly up to the point where you reach the planet where the Valley of the Jedi is located, maybe halfway through the game.I should clarify my old remark on the game's "middling-quality" level design. It's not middling-quality. In fact it's remarkably good, giving you a firm sense of scale, location, and continuity. I'm legitimatly impressed that they managed to stretch a single starship across two or three levels without ever giving you the impression that you've visited the bulk of it. Sure it's very game-y in the sense that navigating them is far more complicated than one could reasonably expect the people who actually belond there to put up with, but compared to the cramped squiggly hallways and bottomless pit abuse of later entries it does its job very well.However, this falls apart around the halfway point of the game. Once you reach the Valley of the Jedi, the entire rest of the game is spent on that planet, and consists entirely of navigating narrow cliffs and Imperial outposts whose existence is never explained, given that the vilains would never have had a chance to set up this elaborate series of bunkers, ventilation shafts, cardo areas,and drills before you got there, seeing as how they explicitly reached the planet at the same time you did.But more importantly than that mild bit of fridge logic, the real failure of the latter half of the game is that it's just bland. The sets are just as big and interconnected as before, but they now lack context, being little more than a meandering series of setpieces with no obvious purpose, simply stalling time between you and your actual destination. The temple itself, which you spend the entire time trying to reach, is also pretty small by the game's standards, basically just three or four floors of tight corridors until you reach the end and get 'rewarded' with two boss fights in a row and the game ends.So in conclusion while a second playthrough gave me a renewed appreciation for the level design, the latter half is dull enough that I still can't recommend it, especially given how crash-prone the game is.

The objectives were nice, the story (even though lacking) was decent, and the level design was pretty good for its time. Speaking of design, I'm not usually one to care about graphics AT ALL, but there is a such thing as working with limitations and just being lazy and making your game look like crap. Atari 2600 games are an example of games that had primitive graphics, but worked with their limitations and made amazing games like Adventure. Take a game like 'Bubsy 3D', everyone hates it. Sure, the Playstation had 32-bit limitations but masterpieces like Crash Bandicoot didn't seem to have any trouble with looking nice. Bubsy 3D on the other hand was the bare minimum of a game, it was so bland it looked like a game still in alpha. Same with DFII, A game from similar time Thief, was able to look amazing and have great design for its time. DFII makes everyone look like a freaking 90's LEGO Technic figure.Anyways, back to the important part of the game, the gameplay and story. The gameplay is pretty much what you would expect, except for the addition of the LightSaber. Honestly, I found myself using the guns more then the LightSaber. I didn't really feel anything from using it, I felt like if there was a sword in DOOM that you fought Melee with. There is a reason why it's called a FPS, not a FPM. Anyways, the Lightsaber didn't even work all the time. Sometimes when I tried to block it wouldn't work. The force is another flaw with this game, sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. That's a main flaw about this game, it works when it wants to, like an Apple product. When I shoot lightning it works fine, but try to push something good luck.The story eventually gets really confusing and doesn't really make any sense. At one point I randomly kill the woman who piloted my ship, and some guy with a cyborg eye randomly shoots me with a red ring and says 'You Belong to the Dark Side Now'. This just makes no sense in a Star Wars game, and then I'm apparently so fat that when I fall into a ship it collapses. For me when the story and objectives stop having a point, I stop playing. There's no point to go on any further if there's nothing I feel I should accomplish.If you happen to like it, good, keep on enjoying it. I honestly would not recommend this game if you were a big fan of the first game. I'm just going to forget about this game and play some good old Dark Forces I.

												The sequel to Star Wars: Dark Forces, now with live action cutscenes, lightsabers, Force Powers and Jedi! This game is another nostalgic piece to my 90’s gaming history and once again, another classic in the Star Wars gaming lineup. Once again, it features Kyle Katarn and his journey to becoming a Jedi and stopping Jerec, the main antagonist from becoming all-powerful. The game also does what its predecessor did not do: gives you some moral choices which affect the ending. The cutscenes are fairly comical (especially Jerec), even though the story is once again, in my opinion, fairly dark. Another outstanding game in an outstanding series of games from LucasArts so I recommend you just buy the entire Jedi Knight series.*The game requires DosBox however, with the Steam download, everything will be set up for you to enjoy as soon as the game is downloaded.Story/Characters:You continue to follow Kyle Katarn in his quest for continuing to kick♥♥♥♥♥and saving the galaxy. Characters are given live actors which is either good or bad as your mileage may vary. Looking back at the cutscenes, I find them enjoyable.Gameplay:For the first several levels, you will be doing the old shooting and scooting until you get your lightsaber. From there, its hacking and slashing to victory with Force powers mixed in. The actions you do in-game will affect the “path” you will go down, either with the Light or Dark Side. This includes saving civilians and making choices in the main storyline. As with the last game, you will be fighting mini bosses in the form of Jerec’s Sith cronies. The lightsaber fights are awkward in my experience, as the hit detection seems to be off so you will end up just flailing your weapon around like a madman hoping to get a hit. There are some cool Force powers available however, ones that were not seen in the movies which is a bonus! Graphics:Once again, your mileage will vary. Either you like the 2D pixels of Dark Forces, or the angular and stiff 3D appearance of Dark Forces 2… pick your poison. Regardless, it gets the job done as it is oddly satisfying to see sparks fly when you hit the walls with your lightsaber. I did get this extremely annoying color glitch and it seems many old games have this issue (Starcraft), where the colors all turn into a headache inducing, blinding neon such as bright teal and pink. I had to mess with the graphical options in-game which I believe was 3D acceleration and make sure the game ran with Admin powers with the compatibility options enabled.Sound/Music:Enemies make the appropriate noises as they are dismembered by Kyle’s lightsaber of justice or riddled with bolts from the Repeater Rifle. Guns and the lightsaber make their iconic sounds. Lightsabers make their crackling noises as they strike each other in the boss duels, or thermal detonators going off in that Rodian’s face. The music is excellent as it usually is in Star Wars games… the Imperial March is as good as it was in the 90’s, as it is now.Controls:The game allows you to use a joystick or the standard keyboard and mouse. I prefer the latter but I do believe I remember playing it with the joystick when I was a kid. (Note: I did not get very far.) You may also customize hotkeys from everything from moving to weapons to force powers.Replay value:You may play through the Dark and Light side paths and try out all the Force powers but there are no achievements or any real incentives to play over and over.Online:The ancestor to Jedi Knight Jedi Outcast’s multiplayer. Nowadays, there may be some group somewhere in a galaxy far, far away playing this multiplayer if you look hard enough but I have never played it. ---***If there are any mistakes to the facts pertaining to the game, please let me know. Also, if you have further questions not covered by the review, or if something were unclear, I will try to clarify as best as possible. Thanks!

												(This is my entry for the Old School Thematic Review Competition)Quick Note:People interested in buying Dark Forces II will probably be concerned about compatibility. So, does it work? The answer is no, probably not. If your hardware supports DirectX 9.0 or above, Dark Forces II will experience numerous graphical errors. However, there is a user-made patch that forwards broken functions to working DX7 functions, solving any graphical errors. This patch should have been packaged with the steam version, considering most people who use steam probably have a graphics card that is less than seven-ish years old.Review:In Dark Forces II, you step into the shoes of Kyle Katarn as he tracks down his father's murderers. He quickly discovers that Jeric, a Dark Jedi responsible for his father's death, has embarked upon a journey to find the "Valley of the Jedi", a source of power that would make him virtually invincible. Kyle travels home and is granted a lighsaber, and is then able to unlock and evolve his force powers as he confronts Jeric and other Dark Jedi. Your available powers and the game's story adapt to your choices. These choices will eventually lead you down the path to the dark or light side of the force.The multiple endings are unparalleled even by more modern games, and this introduces a fantastic level of replayability. The replay factor is further increased by an array of secrets hidden in each of the levels that are quite fun to hunt down. You can use powers like speed and jump to reach previously unreachable areas, so upgrading your powers in different areas will yield different secrets, and a different overall gameplay experience.The gameplay itself is very fun. Dark Forces gave people lightsaber control for the first time, and the level of immersion that it achieves ranks much higher than more modern Star Wars games, such as The Force Unleashed. You are also granted an arsenal of guns, crossbows, rockets, and grenades (along with special attacks on a few of them) to wipe out entire fortresses of enemies. The introduction of 3D graphics also allow you to move into third-person mode, which is a preferable viewpoint for control of your lightsaber. Later in the game, you can unlock powers such as force lightning, grip, throw, and more. The introduction of new elements through the entire game keeps combat exciting and non-repetitive.There are cutscenes after most levels that feature live actors on pre-rendered backgrounds. Although the rendering was very good, some of the acting was pretty bad in my opinion. However, the actor playing Kyle, the protagonist, is fairly good, and I still looked forward to the cutscenes.In terms of graphics and design, all of the levels are completely unique. I've played a few games from this same era, and a lot of them are quite brown and lifeless. The game designers did a very good job of incorporating different colors and worlds into the game, giving you an excellent sense of where you were. One level even takes place on a stinking ship, distorting gravity and allowing you to run up walls and elevator shafts (something that you probably saw in Episode III, however this was done many years before).There was also 3D sound incorporated that game developers reportedly "tweaked extensively" to give whole new level to the immersion already present. This is something that a lot of gamers take for-granted today, but we have to remember that modern sound is "standing on the shoulders of giants", LucasArts undoubtedly being one of the giants in the industry.Overall, Dark Forces II is a very good and innovative title. It introduced many concepts that were never before seen in gaming, and executed them perfectly. The amount of work put into this game is something we don't often see in the cash-cows of today's gaming industry, and it can be clearly seen in the game's immense success. Dark Forces II is a timeless classic that will always be held close to the hearts of Star Wars fans. I highly recommend that you play it, it's an absolutely fantastic game!

												Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is the second game in the Jedi Knight Series.  With some new tech in the engine, actually its a whole new engine.  Some keen ideas in the story, and a few role-playing game elements mixed in.  Jedi Knight is a visible step up from the path that Dark Forces paved.  But just how much of a step is it, and will it surpass its predecessors Breakdown?Jedi Knight, in my opinion, has some of the best story telling I’ve seen in games of its era.  It uses what has almost become a lost art, full motion video.  So many games today are switching over to scripted sequences that are rendered right in the game with the engine carrying the load.  While this can be a great tool for the story telling, at times the better tool is a FMV sequence.  The other great thing about Jedi Knight’s FMV’s are that they use live actors.  Actual people interacting with the CGI characters at the CGI locations.  That does a great job of putting you in the world with a small graphic budget.Jedi Knight had very little compatibility issues, I simply installed it within Steam and in minutes was playing.  At first I had some interesting graphical problems, but with a little help from the Steam Community I got things working in fine order.  The resolution is changeable, but 1280 x 1024 is the highest it goes.  Which was not issues for me, since that’s what I operate with these days.The game does play full screen, but it goes windowed in between levels and to show the FMV’s.  This sometimes caused issues where the full screen shows a blinking or faded border.  Not a game breaker, but was just an eye-sore.Controls were a bit clunky, especially the lightsaber combat.  Fighting Storm Troopers was easy enough, but once you had to fight another Jedi it became a real conflict.  There was a definite delay from mouse-click to saber-swing, which made fighting the more challenging foes that much more challenging.  Also Jedi Knight has a auto-aim feature, something akin to the games predecessors, like Doom and Quake.  You only need aim in the general direction and the game will make sure the target is hit.  There are times where this is great and brings the skill level of the game down a notch or two, and a couple points where its an annoyance.The grenades, or Thermal Detonators as the game would call them, even though actual Thermal Detonators would be far more powerful than what appears in the game.  Either way, they are virtually useless.  A simple click while holding one will practically drop it at your feet.  You throw them at an odd arc that I was unable to get the hang of during my play.  By holding down the fire button you can throw the Det further, but the angles were too hard for me to master and I typically just threw it into the wall or ceiling.Jedi Knight has a Light/Dark pseudo system.  There is a point in the story where you make the choice of Light or Dark.  This choice is made for you, based on your actions up to that point.  If you were bad and killed too many non-hostile NPC’s then you’ll go the dark route.  I was actually bummed when I got the dark route.  I’d known I had killed a few non-hostiles, but had hoped it wasn’t too many.  And unfortunately I had learned about the prospect of different endings too late into the game, and didn’t want to start it all over again.  So I had just been hoping for the best.The levels are fairly par for the time.  Mostly inside buildings, with doors, switches, and decent lighting.   Most of the maps have you searching for a key or switch to unlock the other side of the map.  Often this is easy enough, however there were a couple times where the door or switch was annoyingly hard to locate.  In many cases doors are simply a different sheet metal looking texture, and have no marking to show its a door.  And switches can be found in some very strange places.  There was many a time where I strafed walk along a wall rapidly tapping the ‘Use’ key.  Jedi Knight also makes sure to fill the Star Wars cliche of massive bottomless chasms to fall into.The maps are typicality very large, you can tell the developers were going for that classic Star Wars feel of large spaces.  Many times you can see out windows or over ledges to these vast expanses.   These must have looked nicer years ago.  Because now I feel a lot of the effect is lost in the lower end graphics.  You can clearly see the repeating textures and where the map surface ends and the skybox begins.  Sometimes this is hidden fairly well with fading, as a way to try and preserve the feel of distance.Overall the game is pretty solid.  It has parts that have short comings, but they all fit together nicely.  Showing just how solid of a game it was back in its day.  It shows a good level of improvement from its predecessor, which raises hopes of a continues level of improvement into the rest of the series.  There are far worst games from the late nineties that you could play.With a few exceptions, one of the biggest being the headaches some of these older games cause, I did enjoy my time with Jedi Knight.  It was nice to venture back in time with Kyle Katarn.  I know him well in many Star Wars novels, but finally get to take the time to really learn his backstory.

												Star Wars: Fark Forces II is considered a classic to many from the gaming community.  Released in 1997, this game ushered in a new era of gaming, specifically for the first person shooter, that was predicated by games such as Quake and Wolfenstein where simply running and gunning was the only play style that counted.  Then came Dark Forces II and its ability to deliver gaming narrative, something that had not previously been seen in the shooter genre, with interactive storytelling through live action cut scenes and a storyline that could actually be influenced based upon your actions throughout the game.  While this aspect was great, the gameplay itself carrys Jedi Knight far as well.  With solid controls, impressive sounds and music that come direct from the Star Wars universe, great visuals for a game released in 1997, and an array of weapons and powers that create multiple play sytles and tactics, Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is a game that continues to stand the test of time.  Thanks to it, games such as Half-Life and the like (the story based shooter) were able to become a legitimized powerhouse in the gaming community and continue to rule the shooter community.  Very much worth the $4.99 Steam price tag.  May the Force be with you!

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Jedi Knight is perhaps one of the greatest Star Wars games ever created. Combining FMV cutscenes (with decent effects and acting, to boot) and adventurous first-person shooter gameplay from the late 90s, it's the rare old gem where graphics don't matter, and the atmosphere yanks you out of reality and into the world of the game. The addition of the lightsaber combat and the Force power and alignment system only adds to the immersion, and while its sequels may have improved on the saber combat, Jedi Knight's simple jousting is still remarkably engaging. Featuring a simple yet elegant plot and some of the more memorable characters to be produced by the Star Wars Expanded Universe, the game ensures that each level carries its own weight, and that nothing feels forced or stretched. Though the graphics have not aged well, a few fixes kindly provided by the community will have this baby up and running in no time. If you're a Star Wars fan, an old-school adventure or FPS afficianado, or just looking for  a game with a solid balance between gameplay and narrative, Jedi Knight has you covered. Spend the five bucks and buckle up.

												Yeah, I'm not gonna lie. This game has not aged well, in the slightest. The jedi experience is poorer than bantha fodder, dried under the Tatooine sun. The overall lack of oomph in force powers makes you facepalm, but it's nothing compared to the double facepalm that is the lightsaber. One in particular, Saber Battle X, gives a jedi experience that is albeit, not very fancy, but quite fun and challenging. The neutral force powers actually give Jedi Outcast/Academy a run for its money. There are also several dozen deathmatch mods that have some very fun and interesting weapons as well. There is also no shortage of maps either. You could spend dozens upon dozens of hours playing through all the maps that are available. Sure, getting a group of friends together to experience all this content is a longshot, but these gems exist and await any who dare to give them a look-see!www.Massassi.net hosts most of the said mods & maps.

The force hasn't aged wellDark forces 2 was the first star wars game I've played. I rememeber going to the library, burrowing and playing through it. I couldn't get past the first level back then though... After over a decade and having played the rest of the jedi knight series (Played a bit of dark forces 1 and completed the rest), I thought it would be nice to return to this game. In Dark forces 2, you play as Kyle Katarn, an ex-imperial stormtrooper who is trying to get some payback on the people responsible for killing his father.The Good- Wide range of weapons = including pistol, blasters, smg, grenades, bowcaster, rocket launcher, lightsaber etc.- Light Sabre battles- Good environment variety = You will go to canyons, farmsteads, imperial bases, Nar Shadaa and many other places across your adventure.- 21 single player missions = composed of around 7 boss battles and 14 standaard levels.- Lots of hidden secrets in each level- Different endings based on force allignment- Decent number of force powers- Classic star wars sound effects- Decent, although cheesy, story = Mainly due to the not so great acting by the characters.- Has multiplayer mode- Wide range of foes = Including stormies, officers, rodians, gamoreans, bugs, walkers.The Bad- Constant crashes when launching game for windows 8 and up (can be fixed though).- Constant crashes when choosing to restart level.- Ocassional crashes when saving/loading.- Menu screen and cutscenes does not have wide screen support (can be fixed apparently).- May need walkthrough as you will get lost trying to find where to go.- Some annoying/unfair boss fights.- Missing background music = You can mod it back in, but doesn't loop.- Poor map = you can't use it to navigate where you are or where you need to go.- You can only upgarde force powers at the end of the level = becomes a major problem in boss fights when certain powers can make your life alot easier.- No quick savesFinal verdictSurprisingly, I enjoyed my playthrough of dark forces 2 despite the constant crashes and other obstacles I had to jump over. However, I strongly recommend you purchase the GOG version over this as it has better support for newer systems, runs better, DRM free and fixed a ton of glitches.

												Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II was the first video game I've ever played back when I used the classic Windows 98. To this day I still have my copy of the game in working condition.**Story Info|Possible Spoilers**The game is set one year after the events of Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi. Former mercenary Kyle Katarn meets an info broker droid named 8t88 who informs Katarn that is father, Morgan, was killed by Jerec, a Dark Jedi with plans of rebuilding the Empire. Kyle is given a disk from 8t88 that only a droid in his father's home can read. Kyle Katarn sets out to find this droid and put an end to Jerec's plans to keep the galaxy at peace.**Gameplay**Dark Forces II much like its predecessor is a First Person Shooter, but now you are given the option to use a 3rd person camera if you so desire. The main game is divided into 21 levels, each with an objective and are completed in order.Given at your disposal are various weapons, explosives, and various force powers categorized as Light Side or Dark. later on you'll get a lightsaber after finding Morgan Katarn's droid.The lightsaber combat in Dark Forces II is very primitive and therefore feels dated. You can swing the saber diagonally left and right standing in place, swing in the direction you are moving, do a "fury" attack when moving forward, and a power attack using right-click on the mouse.The gameplay overall is slightly dated, but I think still holds up to today.**Graphics**Do not expect the graphics to be outstanding! Since this is a game from 1997, the graphics are blocky, pixelated, and at times messy. However, for 1997 standards, it's good for its time... Assuming you are not playing it with the 3D Hardware Acceleration disabled, then it just looks bad.**Verdict**Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II is still a blast to play 17 years later, but don't be surprised by its dated feeling. I consider it to be up there with my personal top 5 Star Wars games. As a guy who has been playing it all his life, I definitely recommend you get this game. This is not one you should pass up!

												I think this may be one of the most poorly optimised retro releases to ever be pushed onto the steam storefront.Let me get this out of the way by saying this is solely a judgement of the Steam release, there is a good chance that the GOG release actually works.When I initially bought this, the game had no soundtack, constant graphical glitches (Turning the entire screen into something the Lucky Charms Leprechaun would throw up) and extremely stiff and jerky controls. And by Stiff and Jerky I mean that actual aiming was nigh impossible and I had to resort to playing with the arrow keys to aim. It wasn't fun.However today, I learned that the steam release recieved a patch mid-this year that fixed a lot of the issues that plagued the game upon release. But...It's still broken. The controls are still floaty and the game constantly changes between screen resolutions when you press pause. Only this time there are no windowed cutscenes. The Menus are filled with options that are convoluted and even when attempting to modify in order to make the game run better, don't help. The base controls themselves are bizarrely mapped, there is an underlying disconnect when having to cycle through two mimi-menus containing Force Powers and Items, each with different buttons, and weapons (which you cannot cycle through with the mouse wheel) are awkward to switch between, so I guess you can add a third in-game menu to that as well.Even though using a lightsaber in combat is persuaded, It is not fun to use in a first person perspective and the aforementioned botched controls make it tiring to use and player death is constant when using it.This all come to a conclusion when I entered a Dual Boss fight with two Dark Jedi; one a Damage Sponge Boss (a trope I despise in games) who has an unavoidable choke attack, the other a little gremlin guy who could turn jump around everywhere and turn invisible of all things. To quote a certain lovable rogue "That's not how the force works!"After emptying all my rockets and thermal detonators into them, they were somehow still standing and I was forced to jump and slash at them with a lightaber. 'This is not a good boss fight', I thought as I broke my legs from falling down a suspened platform, again. I quicksaved a lot until finally winning the fight. Nothing happened so I assumed that a door had opened somewhere, the broken and floaty controls made me fall down the aforementioned suspened platform and die. After defeating the boss again. I quicksaved, only for the game to go into a cutscene an promptly crash.I will not be playing this game again.What else is there to say? The Soundtack is typical Star Wars, orchestral and epic, the graphics are from 1997, no point in judging them. Everything else about this release is a disaster though. Please do not buy the Steam release of Dark Forces II. If you really want a good Star Wars game, try the original Dark Forces, at least that game works.

												Finally got around to play Dark Forces 2 and they really stepped up their game in this one. You continue from the first game in a story that finally brings in the almighty lightsaber and Jedi. But wait they are killing innocents so they must be sith. No they’re Jedi, but they are “dark” Jedi. I don’t know the difference nor do I care, but I digress. I won’t get into the story, but you basically go around trying to find this droid who takes your stuff and you learn that some of that stuff holds info on the Jedi temples and that you are force prone. You get a kick♥♥♥♥♥light saber and begin to learn the ways of the force while encountering the “Dark Jedi” along the way.Just like the first game you get a lot of weapons and that keeps the game relatively fresh and the learning of force powers makes it easy to get to certain places and obtain secrets as well as level progression. Unlike the first game you can actually look up. The game is now a more sophisticated first person shooter. The force powers are fun, but most of the time, or at least in my case, they were nothing more than helping you get from point A to point B. They didn’t assist you in combat all that much. I mean sure I could use force pull and take the enemies guns, or I could just pull out my own gun and shoot them while running in a circle because the AI can’t hit for♥♥♥♥♥♥ Even in the fights with the Dark Jedi I just ran around and swung my saber and in later battles occasionally healed.The story was good, the game was action packed, still had the confusing maps and navigation, but overall an enjoyable experience. Even though I went light side on my first play through I know you can go dark and get different powers and maybe even a different ending which means the game has replayability.Overall I would rate this game an 8/10. Enjoyed the game, story was fine, and mechanics were introduced which made the game that more interesting.My Advice, even though I didn’t, before you play this game go look for some mods. The game crashed a lot on me and the texture color could only be fixed by picking up something or hitting the ground with my saber. While this didn’t stop me from play it did get annoying. So before you play this just go online and find some mods to help make this game more of enjoyable experience for you.

												In short, this is a great game that I enjoyed immensely and definitely worth a look. I can never finish most modern FPS games. They are either lacking and uninteresting in their gameplay or just a mindless run-and-gun game. Rare are the games where the action is fast-paced, but not too fast or bugged. Gameplay that is fluid and quick, but not mindless. For this reason, older games are often a breath of fresh air, as was the case with this game. I got this game through a Humble Bundle, and I am very pleased that I did. The levels are fun and well thought out, making you think about what you are doing and how you are going to move forward. You also have to pay attention to detail, or risk spending time searching for that lever or button that will get you moving to the next area. At the same time movement is quick, ensuring that the levels don't drag out and get boring and tedious. The action itself is much like newer games. There's a good spread of different weapons, although I tended to prefer the lightsaber once I god it. It was great fun slashing through my opponents. The boss fights are, at normal difficutly, easy and satisfying at the same time. The only exception to this was the final boss fight that was somewhat drawn out and got boring towards the end. Without spoiling anything, the endings depend on how you play and I felt that it made up for the somewhat crap boss fight.  I never really used the force powers much, except for Force Jump. I did use some in the final boss fight, but the actions is more than good enough without the powers and I had a great time blasting and slashing my opponents. This game has the benefit of being a Star Wars game, and therefore able to use the appropriate music. I rarely enjoy the in-game music as much as I did in this game. The music itself is fantastic, well-timed and just that little bit extra that makes this game even greater. A lot of the time I was actually listening to, and enjoying the music as it really set the mood for a specific situation or level. Towards the middle of the game I had constant flashbacks to the Nintendo 64 Star Wars game. Good times. The graphics arent all that great, which is also obvious from the screenshots in the store page. That being said, I got used to it very quickly, and after about 10 minuts I wasn't offering that graphics a thoght. It felt just as natural as when playing Crysis or any other game (not that I enjoyed Crysis anywhere near as much as this game). Also worth a mentions is the cutscenes. I really like this style of doing them and wish more games would do the same. All in all, this is a very good game and I recommend it to any fans of FPS or Star Wars games without hesitation. Be aware that Steam has also been sloppy (again) and the game doesn't work 100%. A few levels in, the game started asking me for CD2 in order to play cutscenes. Naturally, I didn't have one as this is a digital Steam copy, and therefore I had to watch youtube every time I wanted to see the cutscenes which sucks because the cutscenes are awesome, and in the finale you have to find the right video or risk confusion and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ness.I do believe there are some other issues with the Steam version as well, but I didn't really notice (or care). I got this through a bundle so I didn't really care about the smaller issues that the Steam version has, but if you want a better version you might want to take a look at the one being sold on Good Old Games. Rumour has it that GOG has a better version. Also note that the main menu and cutscenes of the game will always be showed in a small window. I don't believe this is related to the Steam version, but rather the fact that this game wasn't designed to run on the hardware we use today. The game itself is always full-screen and works perfectly.
